natural problem: How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ?
natural solution: A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
shows  "card {p. prime p \<and> p mod 39 = 0} = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
shows  "card {p. prime p \<and> p mod 39 = 0} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many prime numbers are there that when divided by 39 leave a remainder of 0? The final answer is 0.

a_1.formal problem:

shows  "card {p. prime p \<and> p dvd 39} = 0"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
shows  "card {p. prime p \<and> p dvd 39} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many prime numbers divide 39? The final answer is 0.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: int and primes :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {p. prime p}"
and h1 : "\<forall>p \<in> primes. p mod 39 = 0"
shows  "card primes = 0"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: int and primes :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {p. prime p}"
and h1 : "\<forall>p \<in> primes. p mod 39 = 0"
shows  "card primes = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The problem can be translated as follows: "Consider the set of all prime numbers. If all numbers in this set are divisible by 39, then how many elements are in this set?" The final answer is "0".

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. prime (p x)"
shows  "card {x. p x mod 39 = 0} = 0"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. prime (p x)"
shows  "card {x. p x mod 39 = 0} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "How many prime numbers are divisible by 39? The final answer is 0."

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. p n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0)"
shows  "card {n. p n \<and> n mod 39 = 0} = 0"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. p n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0)"
shows  "card {n. p n \<and> n mod 39 = 0} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In the set of integers, a property $p$ is defined such that for any integer $n$ with property $p$, $n$ is not divisible by any integer $m$ between 1 and $n$. How many integers have both property $p$ and are divisible by 39? The final answer is 0.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. p n \<longrightarrow> (1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
shows  "card {n. p n \<and> n mod 39 = 0} = 0"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many prime numbers are divisible by $39$ ? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 A prime number is a number whose only divisors are $1$ and itself. If a prime were divisible by $39$, it would have to be divisible by $3$ and $13$ as well since $3$ and $13$ are factors of $39$.
 Thus the "prime" would have too many factors and wouldn't be a prime!
 Thus there are $\boxed{0}$ primes which are divisible by $39$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. p n \<longrightarrow> (1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
shows  "card {n. p n \<and> n mod 39 = 0} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If $p(n)$ is a property that an integer $n$ has if it is greater than 1 and has no divisors other than 1 and itself (i.e., $p(n)$ means $n$ is a prime number), how many prime numbers are divisible by 39? The final answer is 0.
